rapture

Surgeon Generals warning: Smoking "can" or "may" cause various cancers/ heart disease etc....
 Yet it is verified smoking " will" and " does" cause cancer/ heart disease etc...
 Brain washed, addicted, and slaughtered by words?
 Such words like" may" or "can" puts one in the mind set that there is a probability/ or chance that toxic cancerous ingredients "might not" affect their body.......
galton

Surgeon Generals warning: Smoking "can" or "may" cause various cancers/ heart disease etc....
 Yet it is verified smoking " will" and " does" cause cancer/ heart disease etc...
 Brain washed, addicted, and slaughtered by words?
 Such words like" may" or "can" puts one in the mind set that there is a probability/ or chance that toxic cancerous ingredients "might not" affect them.

 
 The Surgeon General uses words like "can" or "may" because there IS a chance that carcinogens may not cause disease in some individuals. Not every smoker gets cancer, and his words are just reflecting that. But I'm not gonna roll the dice and start smoking.
jim's trucking

Surgeon Generals warning: Smoking "can" or "may" cause various cancers/ heart disease etc....
 Yet it is verified smoking “ will” and “ does” cause cancer/ heart disease etc...
 Brain washed, addicted, and slaughtered by words?
 Such words like" may" or "can" puts one in the mind set that there is a probability/ or chance that toxic cancerous ingredients “might not” affect their body.......

 
 The warning on the pack I bought this morning reads:
 
 "SURGEON GENERAL'S WARNING: Cigarette Smoke Contains Carbon Monoxide."
 
 I've seen other warnings on cigarette packs that read:
 
 ".....Cigarette Smoking Causes Cancer."
daewoo

Surgeon Generals warning: Smoking "can" or "may" cause various cancers/ heart disease etc....
 Yet it is verified smoking “ will” and “ does” cause cancer/ heart disease etc...
 Brain washed, addicted, and slaughtered by words?
 Such words like" may" or "can" puts one in the mind set that there is a probability/ or chance that toxic cancerous ingredients “might not” affect their body.......

 
 
 It says exactly what it means. You MAY get cancer if you smoke. While smoking greatly increases your odds of getting cancer, it is by no means a sure thing. Less than half of smokers actually end up with cancer. IF you smoke, you may end up with cancer. You may not.
emclean

How about smoking may cause relation?
 
 Sorry I an 2 weeks in to quitting smoking
 :xbanghead emoticon_cry emoticon_xkill 
 and am still feeling edgy.
rapture

The Surgeon General uses words like "can" or "may" because there IS a chance that carcinogens may not cause disease in some individuals. Not every smoker gets cancer, and his words are just reflecting that. But I'm not gonna roll the dice and start smoking.

 
 
 
 I guess that would depend on how long the person smoked? Nevertheless, the ingredients in cigars, cigarettes..etc...will lead to cancers, heart disease...ect...
emclean

Nevertheless, the ingredients in cigars, cigarettes..etc...will lead to cancers, heart disease...ect...
 jut breathing in Chaciago, or L.A. will do that.
jim's trucking

How about smoking may cause relation?
 
 Sorry I an 2 weeks in to quitting smoking
 :xbanghead emoticon_cry emoticon_xkill 
 and am still feeling edgy.

 
 Let me wish you good luck. I have quit successfully...three times! One period of abstinence lasted six months.
 
 The longer you are a smoker, the harder it is to quit.
emclean
thanks jim, it is my second hard try, last time went 8 mts till a long car trip by myself.
JPSartre12

thanks jim, it is my second hard try, last time went 8 mts till a long car trip by myself.

 
 I smoked for almost 20 years and then went cold turkey....14 years ago.It can be done. Good luck emoticon_xgood
rapture

Had the package said" will "cause Cancer, instead of " may", cause cancer, ask yourself, would you have ever started? CARCINGENIC ingredients can casue what ele's but cancer? Nevertheless, Nicotine by it self, would it reak the same cancerous havoc? I have pregnant friends who just can't quite, despite the babe, I think it is something eles beyond nicotine.... like roachspray for humans.. I wonder sometimes, however, the connection, if people smoke like they play the lottery tickets........
emclean

Had the package said" will "cause Cancer, instead of " may", cause cancer, ask yourself, would you have ever started? 
 
 I would not have cared if the pack said "will make your most fun parts fall off" (OK maybe then, if I had read it) when you are a teen you will live forever, and that bad stuff happens to outers, not to you. When you are a ****** off teen, and the world is coming down around you, why worry about tomorrow?
 
 When I started smoking I was in bad shape. As a teen the problems looked bigger than they were.
Phunting

I agree, kids are well aware of the facts and yet still start. It really wouldn't matter how much you demonise it on the packet.
 
 And exaggerating the treat is defiantly not the answer. For some reason people believe that if you tell a kid something is scary they will believe you and steer clear. They won't and don't. You have to tell the truth, warn accurately and not unduly play up the dangers. Because if you start exaggerating one thing they won't believe you about others (look at marijuana for Gods sake).
The_Comedian

Show kids photos of lungs that are filled with tar and cancer cells.
 Tell them how bad they'll get at sports.
 Increase the price for cigarettes by far.
 Warning signs on the packs have no effect. E.g. in Germany, we introduced warning labels that have to cover at least 1/3 of the pack; result? Some people even started collecting the different warnings! Effect? Zero, no one quit smoking due to this.
 
 
 Although I have to admit that it is easy to quit smoking. I did it 6 times.
 :p
emclean

It comes down to two basic types of people (yes, I know I am stereotyping, and it is never right) those who never picked up the habit, and can't understand why people smoke with those warnings, and those who did start smoking, and can't understand what difference the warnings make.
 I think Denis Leary said it best
 
 You could have cigarettes that were called the warnings. You could have cigarettes that come in a black pack, with a skull and a cross bone on the front, called tumors and smokers would be lined up around the block going, "I can't wait to get my hands on these *%#*** things! I bet you get a tumor as soon as you light up!
JPSartre12

Had the package said" will "cause Cancer, instead of " may", cause cancer, ask yourself, would you have ever started? CARCINGENIC ingredients can casue what ele's but cancer? Nevertheless, Nicotine by it self, would it reak the same cancerous havoc? I have pregnant friends who just can't quite, despite the babe, I think it is something eles beyond nicotine.... like roachspray for humans.. I wonder sometimes, however, the connection, if people smoke like they play the lottery tickets........

 
 Not everyone who smokes gets lung cancer, just as not everyone exposed to the flu virus gets the flu. Carcinogenic coumpounds "may" cause lots of things, including acute poisoning, allergic reactions, liver disease, etc. There are thousands of suspected carcinogens; if you "definitely" got cancer any time you came in contact with one, we'd all be dead.
Maineiac
The warnings are pretty plain to me,unless I was using the warning for a basis of a law suit.
